text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 4.25.6, Estate and Gift Tax, Report Writing Guide for Estate and Gift Tax Examinations.
IRM 4.25.6.1.5, Related Resources paragraph (3) was added to provide a citation to the Servicewide privacy Policy Statement 10-2 located in IRM 1.2.1.17.2.

IRM 4.25.6.2.1 paragraph 1, sentence 2 was deleted. The feature described was obsoleted.
The content in 4.25.6.7 paragraph 1 was deleted. Guidance regarding estate and gift tax claim cases is in IRM 4.25.9. The note following paragraph 1 was moved to paragraph 1.
Editorial changes have been made throughout this IRM. Hyperlinks, legal citations, and IRM references were reviewed and updated as necessary.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS
This material supersedes the July 29, 2019 publication of IRM 4.25.6, Estate and Gift Tax, Report Writing Guide for Estate and Gift Tax Examinations.
AUDIENCE
This section contains instructions and guidelines for Small Business/Self-Employed Estate and Gift Tax Specialty Programs employees.
Report Writing Guide for Estate and Gift Tax Examinations
Program Scope and Objectives
Generation-skipping Transfer Tax Interrelated Computations
) General Overview - This IRM provides general information about the report writing procedures for estate, gift and generation-skipping transfer tax exami- nations. (

) Purpose - This IRM explains Estate and Gift examiner report writing responsi- bilities so that managers, senior-level officials and examiners will be better equipped to prepare and submit accurate reports. (
) Audience - This IRM is for Estate and Gift Specialty Tax managers, examiners and personnel at the campus who process estate, gift and generation-skipping transfer tax returns, refunds and claims. (

) Policy Owner - Director, Examination - Specialty Policy is responsible for the administration, procedures and updates related to the technical guidance and information processing steps and methods speciﬁc to Estate and Gift Tax examiner responsibilities, IRM subsections, and forms created for the examina- tion of returns and claims. (
) Program Owner - Director, Examination - Specialty Examination owns Estate and Gift Tax Examination. (

) Primary Stakeholders - Advisory Collections, Appeals, Counsel, Estate and Gift Tax Workload Selection and Delivery, Specialty Examination, and SB/SE Examination Quality & Technical Support are the primary stakeholders for this IRM. (
) This section provides policies and procedures relating to estate and gift tax program speciﬁc penalty analysis, managerial approval, assessment and abatement. (

) Estate and gift tax examiners and managers assigned to examine and oversee the examination of estate and gift tax returns and issues are responsible for complying with servicewide policies and authorities set forth in IRM
, Servicewide Policies and Authorities, Policy Statements for the Examining Process. (
) Examination of estate and gift tax returns should be conducted in a manner that will promote public conﬁdence as stated in the Mission of the Service. IRM
, Policy Statement
) Section
of P.L.

requires the Service to include an explanation the examination and collection process, as well as information about assis- tance from the Taxpayer Advocate with any ﬁrst report/notice of proposed deﬁciency. Pub
, The Examination Process, will be used for this purpose. (
) Per Statement of Procedural Rules

, examiners should forward any correspondence (or copy), discussions, reports and/or other material to the taxpayer at the same time the documents are sent to the representative. For more detailed information on how to mail correspondence when a POA is involved, see IRM
, Notices and Communications. (

) The National Quality Review System (NQRS) is a web-based review system used by Estate and Gift Tax Policy, Specialty Exam Quality (SEP) to generate and review reports analyzing national quality performance based upon stan- dardized quality attributes set forth in Document

, Estate and Gift Tax Examination Embedded Quality Job Aid. NQRS report data is compiled by QMA on a quarterly basis, but ad hoc reports may be obtained monthly. The use of NQRS is explained in additional detail in IRM
, Manager Embedded Quality Review and Specialty Exam National Embedded Quality Review Programs. (

) Operational Reviews and related NQRS reports are conducted by Territory Managers and the Chief, Estate and Gift Tax, to measure national adherence to quality standards and managerial performance and/or oversight. (

) Customer, i.e. taxpayer, satisfaction reports are generated by SB/SE Operation Support Research on a quarterly basis. These reports provide masked taxpayer narratives that are responsive to a pre-deﬁned set of survey questions. The quarterly survey reports are to be used to identify areas for amination quality improvement. (
) Frequent front-line manager reviews are conducted under the Examination Quality Review System (EQRS), with the frequency based on annual personnel requirements. (
) The following table sets forth Estate and Gift Tax program speciﬁc terms and deﬁnitions: Term Deﬁnition
-Day letter (also known as a preliminary letter) Letter used to transmit the exami- nation report to the taxpayer and allow the taxpayer
days to request Appeals’ consideration of the case, or take other actions as outlined in the speciﬁc letter.

Operational Reviews and related NQRS reports are conducted by Territory Managers and the Chief, Estate and Gift Tax, to measure national adherence quality standards and managerial performance and/or oversight.
4.25.6.1.4(07-29-2019) Terms/Deﬁnitions/Acronyms

Term Deﬁnition 30-Day letter (also known as a preliminary letter) Letter used to transmit the exami- nation report to the taxpayer and allow the taxpayer 30 days to request Appeals’ consideration of the case, or take other actions as outlined in the speciﬁc letter.
Report Writing Guide for Estate and Gift Tax Examinations 4.25.6

and/or penalty. An examined tax period resulting in adjustment(s) that reduce the taxpayer’s liability in the year examined. An overassessment becomes an overpayment when a refund is indicated (subject to the time limits prescribed for making a refund or credit). An examined tax period that results in a deﬁciency, a disal- lowed claim or refund or a change (but the adjustments impact the tax liability of another year), and the taxpayer does not agree to the ﬁndings and a report or waiver is not signed by the taxpayer. A form allowing taxpayers to waive certain restrictions or re- quirements. Estate and Gift Tax generally uses Form
, Waiver of Restrictions on Assessment and Collection of Deﬁciency and Acceptance of Overassessment - Estate, Gift and Generation - Skipping Transfer Tax.

) The Estate and Gift Tax program is required to follow all servicewide examina- tion procedures and those set forth in SB/SE examining process IRM. The following IRM subsections provide additional information relating to the pro- cessing, classiﬁcation and examination of Estate and Gift Tax program returns and claims:

) Document

, Estate and Gift Tax Examination Embedded Quality Job is issued by Estate and Gift Tax Policy, and is relied upon for the application and interpretation of the quality attributes. The Job Aid includes complete in- structions, deﬁnitions, and examples of how cases should be evaluated. (
) IRM
, Policy Statement
, Privacy First: Ethically protecting indi- vidual privacy and safeguarding conﬁdential tax information. This Servicewide Policy statement summarizes existing policy from IRM
, mainly the IRS Privacy Principles section, to emphasize the importance of privacy protections as ethical principles the IRS must follow Servicewide.
) Examination Reports (
) Examiners have the responsibility to ensure examination reports are properly prepared and issued. (

) Examination reports serve several important purposes. Examination reports: a. Protect the taxpayer’s “Right to be Informed.” Examination reports contain all the information necessary to ensure a clear understanding the adjustments and identify the amounts (if any) of tax due, interest ductible, additions to the tax and assessable penalties. b. Serve as the basis for assessment and collection action. c. Give notice of a tax liability for purpose of interest suspension. IRC
(g) provides for the suspension of interest when the Service fails provide timely and adequate notice of a tax liability.
) Notebook Job Aid (

) The Estate and Gift Notebook (EG Notebook) is the only authorized report writer for Estate and Gift. Regardless of the access to other programs or systems capable of preparing reports, all Examination Reports must be utilizing Notebook. (

) Issue Management System (IMS) users may export data from IMS into the Notebook case ﬁle. The exported IMS data includes the TIN, taxpayer name, taxpayer contacts, and ERCS data. See The Estate and Gift Tax Notebook Aid Job Aid (EG Notebook Job Aid), for instructions on importing data into exporting data from Notebook.
) Notebook Job Aid Technical Support (
) The EG Notebook Job Aid is accessible through Notebook, under the Help/Tips tab. (

) Submit a help ticket to obtain technical support or assistance with Notebook data entry procedures. For proper routing of the service ticket, use “Estate Gift Notebook” in the text describing the issue.
) Notebook Order of Adjustment (

) The examiner should enter all adjustments into Notebook using the following order of adjustments: a. Manual-only adjustments (e.g., increase to a Schedule B item or decrease to Schedule K item) b. Adjustments that can be manually input or have a Worksheet option (e.g., Adjusted Taxable Gifts/Aggregate Tax on Gifts) c. Adjustments that require the use of a Worksheet (e.g., interrelated putations, including interrelated interest).
Estate and Gift

a. Protect the taxpayer’s “Right to be Informed.” Examination reports should contain all the information necessary to ensure a clear understanding of the adjustments and identify the amounts (if any) of tax due, interest de- ductible, additions to the tax and assessable penalties. b. Serve as the basis for assessment and collection action. c. Give notice of a tax liability for purpose of interest suspension. IRC
(g) provides for the suspension of interest when the Service fails to provide timely and adequate notice of a tax liability.
Manual

only adjustments (e.g., increase to a Schedule B item or decrease to Schedule K item) Adjustments that can be manually input or have a Worksheet option (e.g., Adjusted Taxable Gifts/Aggregate Tax on Gifts) Adjustments that require the use of a Worksheet (e.g., interrelated com
putations, including interrelated interest).
Report Writing Guide for Estate and Gift Tax Examinations 4.25.6
) Adjustments that require the use of Worksheet (e.g., interrelated computations, including interrelated interest) should be entered in the following order:
Marital/Charitable/GSTT Interrelated computations
Penalties Drawing Interest
State Death Tax Deduction and State Interest Deduction
Federal Interrelated Interest or

Interrelated Interest Note: If the examiner deviates from the above order of adjustments, calculations viewed on the preview screens may not be fully updated. Deploying Report Forms (from the Case Details screen) updates all calculations. (
) The following sections provide guidance and best practices for generating estate and gift examination report forms using Notebook. (

) Prepare the applicable Examination Report forms for issuance to the taxpayer and authorized representatives. Generally, the Estate and Gift Tax Return Ex- amination Report must include the following: a. Form
, Report of Estate Tax Examination Changes, is used to show the recommended adjustments. The form has two columns: “Tax Previ- ously Assessed/Shown on Return” and “As Corrected” tax. The Form

shows the recommended net deﬁciency or over-assessment of The amounts entered in the “Shown on Return/As Previously Assessed” are the assessed tax and penalty amounts shown on a current transcript. These entries may differ from those shown on the return. Form

contains a summary of the adjustment in tax and a computation of the estate tax. Note: Review Integrated Data Retrieval System (IDRS) transcripts of the account to ensure that the correct assessed tax and penalties are reﬂected on all reports. The IDRS transcript should be current, i.e. no older than
days. b. Form
, Report of Gift Tax Examination, is used for gift tax examina- tions. c. Form
, Adjustment to Taxable Estate, is used to summarize the net change on each schedule of the Form
d. Form

-A, Explanation of Items, is used in estate or gift tax reports explain each adjustment shown in the columns entitled “Shown on Return” and “As Corrected.” The adjustments are entered in numerical order as reﬂected on the original return (Form
or Form
) schedule. Each Form
-A should be printed, titled, treated individually and organized in alphabetical order. A full and adequate description of each adjustment should be included on Form

-A. e. Exhibits, worksheets, computations and other relevant documents necessary to explain changes to the taxpayer should be attached when appropriate. f. When an engineer, economist, or other expert report is prepared and the ﬁndings accepted by the examiner, the copy designated “Taxpayer’s Copy” should be attached as an exhibit to the Form
or Form
the examiner previously submitted the report to the taxpayer, an additional copy of the appraisal does not need to be attached to the report. These actions should be documented on the Form
, Activity Record. (
) Internal Revenue Manual
Adjustments that require the use of Worksheet (e.g., interrelated computations, including interrelated interest) should be entered in the following order:
Marital/Charitable/GSTT Interrelated computations Penalties Drawing Interest State Death Tax Deduction and State Interest Deduction Federal Interrelated Interest or
Interrelated Interest

Note: If the examiner deviates from the above order of adjustments, calculations viewed on the preview screens may not be fully updated. Deploying Report Forms (from the Case Details screen) updates all calculations.
The following sections provide guidance and best practices for generating estate and gift examination report forms using Notebook.
4.25.6.4(12-07-2021) Estate and Gift Examination Report Forms
Prepare the applicable Examination Report forms for issuance to the taxpayer and authorized representatives. Generally, the Estate and Gift Tax Return Ex
amination Report must include the following:
a. Form
, Report of Estate Tax Examination Changes, is used to show the recommended adjustments. The form has two columns: “Tax Previ- ously Assessed/Shown on Return” and “As Corrected” tax. The Form

shows the recommended net deﬁciency or over-assessment of tax. The amounts entered in the “Shown on Return/As Previously Assessed” are the assessed tax and penalty amounts shown on a current transcript. These entries may differ from those shown on the return. Form
also contains a summary of the adjustment in tax and a computation of the estate tax. Review Integrated Data Retrieval System (IDRS) transcripts of the account
Form
, Report of Gift Tax Examination, is used for gift tax examina- tions. Form
, Adjustment to Taxable Estate, is used to summarize the net change on each schedule of the Form
Form

-A, Explanation of Items, is used in estate or gift tax reports to explain each adjustment shown in the columns entitled “Shown on Return” and “As Corrected.” The adjustments are entered in numerical order as reﬂected on the original return (Form
or Form
) schedule. Each Form
-A should be printed, titled, treated individually and organized in alphabetical order. A full and adequate description of each adjustment should be included on Form

-A. Exhibits, worksheets, computations and other relevant documents necessary to explain changes to the taxpayer should be attached when appropriate. When an engineer, economist, or other expert report is prepared and the ﬁndings accepted by the examiner, the copy designated “Taxpayer’s Copy” should be attached as an exhibit to the Form
or Form
the examiner previously submitted the report to the taxpayer, an additional copy of the appraisal does not need to be attached to the report. These actions should be documented on the Form
, Activity Record.
g. Except for the ﬁnal report included in the closed case ﬁle, all draft reports sent to the taxpayer should be stamped or labeled “DRAFT” and dated. h. Form

, Estate Tax Waiver of Restrictions on Assessment and Collec- tion of Deﬁciency and Acceptance of Over-Assessment, is used to document that the taxpayer agrees to the proposed adjustments and is waiving the statutory restrictions upon assessment and collection of the deﬁciency in tax. The execution of this form permits the Service to assess the deﬁciency, schedule the over-assessment, or adjust the appli- cable credit amount immediately; It also stops the running of interest the
st day after the date of receipt until notice and demand for payment is made. Form
does not constitute a ﬁnal closing agreement. Receipt of a signed waiver does not preclude reopening of the examination by the taxpayer or by the Service. Form

is used fully and partially agreed cases. The report should reﬂect the exact amount of the deﬁciency, over-assessment, applicable credit amount, and/or penalty agreed to. The examiner should neither alter the amounts on a signed waiver nor solicit a blank signed waiver. Note: Form
should be date stamped when received. The Form
received date should also be notated in the examiner’s Form
, Activity Record. i. If the amounts shown on the signed Form

are incorrect due to an error in computation, and the error would result in an incorrect billing or refund, the report will be re-written for the corrected amount and a statement will be made on the report explaining the change. Reviewing transcripts for penalties, tax assessments, and payments before preparing a draft report will reduce most computation errors. If the correction is in favor of the taxpayer, it is not necessary to obtain a new waiver. If the rection is against the taxpayer, a supplemental waiver for the difference between the corrected amount and the amended amount will be secured. The supplemental waiver will be clearly marked as such and stapled on top of the original waiver. Note: Form

-T, Waiver of Restrictions on Assessment and Collection and Acceptance of Overassessment as to Transferee or Fiduciary Liability for Estate, Gift and Generation—Skipping Transfer Tax, is used for agreed transferee liability cases. See IRM
, Special Examination Procedures, Transferee Liability Cases Worksheets by Notebook (

) Except for penalties, most gift adjustments may be made manually through Notebook. (
) The gift worksheets show the underlying tax computations for the adjustments described on the Form

The execution of this form permits the Service to assess the deﬁciency, schedule the over-assessment, or adjust the appli- cable credit amount immediately; It also stops the running of interest from the
st day after the date of receipt until notice and demand for payment is made. Form

are incorrect due to an error in computation, and the error would result in an incorrect billing or refund, the report will be re-written for the corrected amount and a statement will be made on the report explaining the change. Reviewing transcripts for penalties, tax assessments, and payments before preparing a draft report will reduce most computation errors. ) Except for penalties, most gift adjustments may be made manually through Notebook. (
) The gift worksheets show the underlying tax computations for the adjustments described on the Form

) Accounting for Changes in the Law Impacting post-
Gift Tax Reports Worksheet (
) This post-
worksheet accounts for changes in the law impacting post-
gift tax return reports. The worksheet mirrors the table computations outlined the Form
instructions. The worksheet computes the applicable credit prior periods and gift tax paid in prior periods by taking into consideration • From
through
, the top rate on gifts was
percent. Starting in
, the top rate on gifts increased to
percent. • The uniﬁed credit for
was $
, and is now indexed for inﬂation. See for current credit information. • Any uniﬁed credit allocated to gifts made in periods prior to
be recalculated using current gift tax rates. (

) The Notebook Help/Tips tab includes a PDF document with instructions for counting for the changes to the prior uniﬁed credit. The PDF document also includes screen shot examples of the computation process. These instructions are also in the EG Notebook Job Aid. (

) Deploy and print the Prior Uniﬁed Credit Computation Sheet. Include the Uniﬁed Credit Computation Sheet as a report exhibit to show any adjustments made to the prior uniﬁed credit. This worksheet should also be uploaded IMS as a part of the report workpapers. (
) When examining estate tax returns, the examiner should also document the reasons for changing uniﬁed credit allocations for prior gift tax return periods.
) Adjusted Taxable Gifts/Aggregate Tax on Gifts Worksheet (
) This Adjusted Taxable Gift and Aggregate Tax on Gifts worksheets verify Adjusted Taxable Gifts and calculate the correct Aggregate Tax on Gifts, including an IRC
(b) adjustment when appropriate.
) Generation-skippin
ransfe
ax(Schedul
)Worksheet (

) This Adjustment may be made manually or input by using the Generation- skipping Transfer Tax (Schedule C) worksheet (use of the worksheet is recommended). If manually-input, select the Adjustment Type and complete ﬁelds. See the EG Notebook Job Aid, for instruction for determining the amount of the adjustment by using the worksheet.
) Penalties in a Gift File (
) Penalties in a gift tax ﬁle cannot be entered manually. The “Gift Penalty” worksheet must be used.
) As Returned/Previously Assessed Penalties in Gift File (
) Obtain a current BMFOL transcript to verify any previously assessed penalties. (
) From the “As Returned” gift input screen, enter the as returned values from return and click the “+” sign next to the Penalties Previously Assessed tion to enter previously assessed penalties. (

) After clicking the “+” sign next to Penalties Previously Assessed, enter the Returned/Previously Assessed penalty information for the gift tax ﬁle as on the transcript data. Report Writing Guide for Estate and Gift Tax Examinations

This Adjustment may be made manually or input by using the Generation

Obtain a current BMFOL transcript to verify any previously assessed penalties.
Penalties in (

) To enter gift tax penalty adjustments, select the relevant gift year, then select Penalties from the Adjustments screen drop-down menu. The penalty screen will open automatically: a. Select the “Use the Worksheet to Compute Corrected Penalty Calcula- tions” box b. Select the appropriate Gift Year c. Select the Penalty Type from the Add/Edit Penalty Drop Down Menu (

) To calculate a combination of Failure to File/Failure to Pay Penalties: a. If there are approved ﬁling and/or payment extension dates, enter them in the FTF Penalty Computation Date and/or FTP Penalty Computation Date ﬁelds. b. Always verify the ﬁling and payment deadlines with a current transcript. Verify payments and the tax subject to FTF and FTP. See IRC

c. In the upper right portion of the screen, enter all payment information (dates and amounts). Click Add Payment for each entry. d. If the Substitute for Return (SFR) rule applies, check the “Apply SFR” box. (

) After inputting adjustments for all years in examination, click the “Update Data” button, if applicable. This action imports the examination changes into the Prior Uniﬁed Credit (PUC) Computation Sheet. The “Update PUC Data” button appears only if there are both pre-
adjusted taxable gifts and a post-
estate tax and/or gift tax return under examination. (
) IRC
Accuracy/Negligence and IRC
Fraud penalties may also be entered from this screen. (

) If as a courtesy the examiner wants to provide an estimate of interest on a tax (or gift tax plus penalties) assessment, the examiner should use the Gift Interest icon (shown at the top of the Gift File) and input the following informa- tion into the Gift Interest Worksheet and select deploy: a. Gift Year b. Amount Drawing interest c. Correct Due Date d. Date of Payment (estimated payment date set by examiner) Worksheets by Notebook (
) This section provides instructions for completing various estate ﬁle report sheets in Notebook. (

) For additional assistance go to the Help/Tips pull-down menu within Notebook. The Help/Tips pull-down menu offers speciﬁc help and tips for new estate report drafting procedures, and provides direct access to the EG Notebook Aid. (

) Most of the worksheet calculations described below may also be entered Notebook manually. If the worksheet calculation is a variable in the interrelated computation the worksheet option must be used. It is recommended that the examiner use the worksheet calculations as the default method for all cases with interrelated or
election computations.
Estate and Gift
Report Writing Guide for Estate and Gift Tax Examinations 4.25.6
Credit (

) A gift tax credit adjustment may be made manually or by using a worksheet. a. If the credit is limited to a ﬁxed dollar amount, use a manual entry for gift tax credit. b. If the credit is not limited to a ﬁxed dollar amount, use the Gift Tax Credit Worksheet. (
) The Gift Tax Credit Worksheet corresponds to the Form
, line
gift tax credit on pre-
gifts. The Worksheet functions as an alternative to Form
(gift tax credit manual worksheet). (
) To open the Worksheet, on the Miscellaneous tab of the Adjustments screen, select Gift Tax Credit from the Adjustment Type drop-down list and click Worksheet. (
) To include the gift tax credit as a variable in the interrelated computation the examiner must use the Gift Tax Credit Worksheet. Additionally, for a Section
election the examiner must use the Gift Tax Credit Worksheet to ensure the credit is factored into the
calculations. Prior Transfers (

) A tax on prior transfers credit (TPT) adjustment may be made manually or by using the Tax on Prior Transfer Credit worksheet (TPT Credit worksheet). If credit is limited to a ﬁxed dollar amount, use a manual entry. (
) The TPT credit worksheet corresponds to the Form
, line
, and functions as an alternative to Form

, Computation of Credit for Tax on Prior Transfers. The TPT Credit worksheet is based on the input of transferor’s tax information. Notebook will calculate the Transferee computation (second limitation) to determine the correct amount of the credit, and reﬂect the results on the respective Form
-A worksheet. See the EG Notebook Job Aid for data entry instructions. (
) To include the TPT credit as a variable in the interrelated computation the examiner must use the TPT Credit Worksheet. Additionally, for a Section
election the examiner must use the TPT Credit Worksheet to ensure the credit is factored into the
calculations. (
) Include the TPT Credit worksheet, Form

, Computation of Credit for Gift Tax, (if applicable) in Part II, when there is an adjustment in the amount of credit claimed or the Gift Tax Credit worksheet generated by Notebook. The applicable schedules and computations showing the net value of the trans- ferred property should be attached. Death Tax Credit (Statutory)/Foreign Credit (Treaty/Canadian Marital Worksheet (

) A Foreign Death Tax Credit (FDTC) adjustment may be made manually or by using a worksheet. a. If the credit is limited to a ﬁxed dollar amount, use a manual entry for appropriate credit. b. To include the Foreign Death Tax Credit as a variable in the interrelated computation, the examiner must use the Foreign Death Tax Credit Worksheet. Additionally, for a Section
election, the examiner must use the Foreign Death Tax Credit worksheet to ensure the credit is factored into the
calculations. c. See the EG Notebook Job Aid, for data entry instructions. Writing Guide for Estate and Gift Tax Examinations
page
J (
) Internal Revenue Manual
A gift tax credit adjustment may be made manually or by using a worksheet.

) To include the estate ﬁle penalties (except accuracy-related penalties) as a variable in the interrelated computation the examiner must use the Penalty Worksheet. Additionally, for a Section
election the examiner must use Penalty Worksheet to ensure the correct amounts are factored into the
calculations. (

) On a transcript, the FTF and FTP penalties are listed separately. If the examiner is making an Adjustment to FTF/FTP (the combination penalty, where FTP reduces FTF), enter the combined total amount of both previously assessed penalties on the Penalties Previously Assessed tab using the “

— Failure to File/Failure to Pay” option from the drop-down list. Entering the penalties separately, followed by use of the FTF/FTP Worksheet to calculate the combination penalty, may yield an incorrect Adjustment result. Use the separate appropriate Worksheets to enter each penalty’s information. See IRM
, Failure to File a Tax Return or to Pay Tax—IRC
, and IRM
, IRC
Penalty Computation Examples. See the EG Notebook Job Aid. (

) To include accuracy, negligence, or fraud penalties in the report select the ap- propriate penalty type from the drop-down menu on the “Penalty Management” screen. See the EG Notebook Job Aid for penalty calculation data entry in- structions. (

) The accuracy, negligence and fraud penalty inputs must be input separately: a. The examiner must separately calculate the “Tax Attributable” to the assets resulting in an accuracy or negligence penalty. b. The examiner must also separately calculate the “Tax Attributable” to fraud. c. The examiner can group all
percent items together in one process,
percent items and fraud items should both be run in their own separate processes. (

) This worksheet requires a manual input of all information. All amounts entered in the “Shown on Return/As Previously Assessed” ﬁelds will carry over to “As Corrected” ﬁelds. As a result, all appropriate “As Corrected” adjustments must be manually entered. See the EG Notebook Job Aid. Function (

(b) “gross up”, it should be treated a speciﬁc bequest. It is recommended that the gross up be identiﬁed as

Gross Up” in the “Name of Speciﬁc Bequest Beneﬁciary” ﬁeld. The on this phantom inclusion item is typically borne by the residue. If not, the tax on the “gross up” must be accounted for as borne by other speciﬁc bequests. (

) The “Marital/Charitable Deductions” screen (including the “Additional Informa- tion” option) provides an option that will allow the user to override the residue ﬁelds to run hypothetical calculations without having to make adjustments elsewhere. (

) Use the State Death Tax Deduction (SDTD) worksheet to correct state estate and inheritance tax computations based upon revisions made during the course of an audit. Calculations may be made for multiple jurisdictions neously. See the EG Notebook Job Aid. (
) The SDTD calculators are Excel workbooks. (

) Limited taxpayer’s data entered in Notebook is imported into the Excel SDTD tax calculator. This data includes the returned gross estate and deductions, and the corrected gross estate and deductions, as needed (varies by jurisdic- tion). The examiner is responsible for completing the entries in the SDTD Excel workbook so that Notebook’s calculations reﬂect both the “As Returned”

screen) derived from the As Returned and Adjustments inputs. These are the “corrected value.” It is important that all appropriate adjustments are made and are reﬂected accurately on the screen. (

) The worksheet is also designed to include deductible interest. The calculation of interrelated deductible interest is a function that should be run after perform- ing any other interrelated computation(s) as described in the order of adjustments discussed in IRM

, Notebook Order of Adjustments. The deductible interest will automatically populate to the “Totals of Schedule J, K, L” ﬁeld on the Marital/Charitable screen after the interest deduction is computed. (
) Certain residue information will also auto-populate from the “As Returned” and“ Adjustments” previously input. The examiner should verify the residue informa-

and “As Corrected” calculations. For example, the value of the adjusted taxable gifts included in the state computations vary by state, therefore, the Federal adjusted taxable gifts ﬁgure is not always the correct ﬁgure for the state calculation. Review the instructions on the state’s Excel workbook and the state form and instructions for assistance with understanding the state culation. (
) It is a best practice to input all adjustments into Notebook except the interre- lated interest deduction at the time the state death tax deductions are calculated. Interest (

) When creating a new estate case that is a claim, set up a “New Taxpayer Case” using the same procedures as setting up any other new case. See EG Notebook Job Aid. (
) When inputting the information regarding the amount of the claim, there two user options:
Report Writing Guide for Estate and Gift Tax Examinations 4.25.6

a. The Notebook claim screen requires a manual entry for all relevant amounts (Estate, GST, Penalties). When using the claim screen option, Notebook automatically calculates the amounts allowed and disallowed based on the “As Returned” and “Adjustments” inputs, to generate the Form
and Form

b. To select the “Fixed Dollar” Amount option, check the “Use Fixed Dollar Amount” box. This option prompts a manual input in the “Amount of Claim”, “Claim Allowed”, and “Claim Disallowed” ﬁelds. This option has limited applicability (e.g., such as surveyed claims.) If the “Claim Allowed” and “Claim Disallowed” amounts do not add up to the “Amount of Claim”, Notebook will prompt the user for veriﬁcation. (

) In the event the examiner has multiple returns (estate and/or gifts) subject claims, the examiner must set up the Estate File and Gift File as a combination case. Use the Estate case “Claim” icon for an estate claim, and the Gift case “Claim” icon for all gift claim(s).
) Miscellaneous Report Tools (
) This section provides information on miscellaneous forms that may need to included in the examination report.
) Estate Tax and Interest Deductions (

) It is not necessary to have all adjustments in Notebook at the time the state death tax calculations and state interest amounts are prepared. It is recom- mended that all adjustments be input into Notebook except the interrelated interest deduction at the time the state death tax deductions are calculated. (

) The state death tax and state interest deductions are calculated using an in- corporated Excel workbook. If there are multiple state death tax jurisdictions issue, each state will require separate data entry. All of the Excel sheet cells (except white numerical cells) are protected from erasure or change and cannot be altered by the user. The taxpayer data entered into Notebook is tomatically imported into the tax worksheet. This data includes the returned gross estate and deductions, and the corrected gross estate and deductions, as deﬁned by each jurisdiction’s state death tax rules. See the EG Notebook Job Aid for instructions on entering state death tax deduction information into the Excel program and then saving the data into Notebook.
) of Deceased Unused (
) For decedents dying after December

, with a surviving spouse, the estate may elect to port the Deceased Spouse Unused Exclusion (DSUE) amount to the decedent’s surviving spouse. The surviving spouse will use ported unused exclusion amount against any future adjusted taxable gifts or against the surviving spouse’s estate tax return liability. (

) There are three DSUE adjustments available within Notebook. • Adjustments to correct overstatements or understatements of DSUE portable to a surviving spouse. • Adjustment to the surviving spouse’s Form
to reduce or increase the amount of DSUE applied to an adjusted taxable gift. • Adjustment to the surviving spouse’s Form
to reduce or increase the amount of DSUE applied to the tentative tax generated by the surviving spouse’s gross estate. Writing Guide for Estate and Gift Tax Examinations

Process (
) From the onset of the examination, the examiner must document and nicate the actions taken by using mandatory and non-mandatory workpapers. See IRM
, Estate and Gift Tax Program Exam Process and Documenta- tion, and IRM
, Estate and Gift Tax Exam Process and Documentation for additional information regarding the completion of mandatory and issue speciﬁc lead sheets. (

) The lead sheets can be found in the Mandatory Forms folder, Lead Sheets folder or the Case Closing folder in the Notebook Forms Library. The examiner may deploy case customized lead sheets and forms from within Notebook. (

) A “Personal Library” is also available for Notebook users. This optional en- hancement allows Notebook users to create their own Word and Excel templates for future customized case deployment. The Personal Library is overwritten by Notebook updates. Letters Notebook (
) Notebook can be used to generate and deploy auto-populated administrative case documents (e.g., Form
) and letters. (

) Closing documents are deployed from Notebook to the case “Closing Forms” folder after the examiner selects the appropriate disposal code. See the EG Notebook Job Aid for instructions on entering disposal codes and deploying closing forms. Notebook will auto-populate the administrative forms with the examiner’s identifying information, taxpayer and case information, disposal codes and tax adjustment information. This information is pulled from the general input screen when the case is created and from the generated forms (e.g., Form
) Notebook will auto-populate the Form
with all related return information since the related returns generally close together. Before closing a related return package, the examiner must manually delete, from the Form
, returns not closing at the same time. When generating the Form
, Notebook generates a pop-up reminder to delete the related returns, from Form
, not closed with the package.
